title: -Ed / -Ing Adjectives
summary: This lesson explains how to use -ed and -ing adjectives formed from verbs, focusing on the difference between describing how someone feels and what causes the feeling.
content: -Ed and -ing adjectives are participial adjectives formed from verbs.
-Ing adjectives describe the thing or situation that causes the feeling.

examples.rule: Use -ed adjectives to describe how someone feels.
examples: We’re tired. Can we stop running?
I was surprised to see her.

examples.rule: Use -ing adjectives to describe the thing or situation that causes the feeling.
examples: Running is very tiring. We don’t want to run.
This film is very boring. Let’s play cards.
Her visit was very surprising. We weren’t expecting her.

tips: Use -ed adjectives for feelings and emotions (e.g., bored, surprised, tired).
Use -ing adjectives for causes of feelings (e.g., boring, surprising, tiring).
